etymology.description: Depicts crossed lines resembling scissors or a shearing motion -> to cut or govern
etymology.interpretation: The character 乂(乂) (yì, 'to govern/cut') visually represents crossed lines, similar to scissors in action. This pictorial form evolved to also symbolize governance, suggesting control or regulation akin to the precision of cutting.

examples.chinese: 圣君乂天下(聖君乂天下)。
examples.english: A sagacious ruler governs the world.

examples.chinese: 皇帝以宽仁乂天下(皇帝以寬仁乂天下)，令百姓安居(令百姓安居)。
examples.pinyin: Huángdì yǐ kuān rén yì tiānxià, lìng bǎixìng ānjū.
examples.english: The emperor governs the world with benevolence, enabling the people to live in peace.

examples.chinese: 厨师用刀乂肉块(廚師用刀乂肉塊)，准备宴席(準備宴席)。
examples.pinyin: Chúshī yòng dāo yì ròukuài, zhǔnbèi yànxí.
examples.english: The chef cuts the pieces of meat with a knife, preparing for the banquet.
